g.text: In addition, glycan chain length depending on
tor binding of inﬂuenza A viruses, as discussed
The HA1 subunit, which carries a receptor
binding site, is responsible for attachment of the
virus to speciﬁc sialyl sugar chains on the host cell
surface. Changes in amino acid residues in the
receptor binding region of HA can cause alteration
of inﬂuenza binding preference. Evidence from mo-
demonstrated that the sialic acid binding site of H1
viruses is located in amino acid positions of 111 to
at the distal tip of each monomer of the HA
trimer, which is formed by three secondary struc-
at the edges of each HA monomer
Substitution of amino acids in the HA receptor
binding region of H1 viruses and a receptor binding
speciﬁc assay revealed that two amino acid residues
at positions 190 and 225 in HA1 are critical as
determinants of receptor binding speciﬁcity, by
which H1 HA carrying E190 and G225 preferentially
2-3 receptors in avians, and H1 HA
possessing D190 and G225 favors both
2-6 receptors in pigs, whereas H1 HA containing
D190 and D225 eﬀectively binds to
type seems to be a prerequisite for the creation of a
human pandemic. All ﬁve 1918 H1N1 viruses from
the Spanish inﬂuenza pandemic have D190 but diﬀer
19 carry G225 identical to swine viruses and an
avian virus adapted to pigs, whereas A
1918 have an additional change from G
to D at position 225. These ﬁndings suggest that
change of amino acid at position 190 (E to D) is likely
to be the minimal change allowing the shift from
binding to avian type receptors to binding to human
This is supported by a ﬁnding that
double mutations at E190D and D225G in huSC18
HA that changed binding preference from human to
avian type receptors (called AV18 mutant) resulted
in abolishment of viral transmission between fer-
there are similarities in virulence, pathology
and immune response to inﬂuenza virus infection
I194, which are highly conserved among the diﬀerent
HA subtypes, are involved in anchoring Neu5Ac
and, thus, the speciﬁcity of binding is governed by
interaction of the HA receptor binding site with the
asialo portion including the glycosidic oxygen atom
and sugars next to the Neu5Ac residue (Fig. 6).
PDB structural information used for analysis in
this review is shown in Table 1. Interaction of the
receptor binding site on the HA of 1930-swine
column) used as a human receptor analog (PDB:
1rvt) is shown in umbrella-like topology in Fig. 6a,
data indicated that there are two critical sets of
HA amino acid residues interacting with long
receptors: (1) K222, D225 and Q226 provide crucial
contacts with the base region, the Neu5Ac
1- motif and (2) D190, Q192 and S193 make
optimal contacts with the extension region, the
contains D225G, which provides only the backbone
carbonyl oxygen of glycine (G) positioned to interact
with the Gal sugar in the base region but lacks extra
Receptor binding studies demonstrated that H1N1
human viruses have higher binding aﬃnity for
SL can be abolished by a
a key role in contact with GlcNAc. E190D and
D mutations were also shown to increase
binding aﬃnity of avian H1 HAs for 6
HA of the pandemic 2009 H1N1 virus, huCA09, has
K222, D225 and Q226 in contact with the base region
and D190, Q192 and S193 in contact with the
extension region of the LSTc human receptor. Addi-
tionally, huCA09 HA has K133a (K133a in huSC18;
R133a in swIowa30), unique K145 (S145 in HA1 of
the other H1N1 viruses) and K156 (K156 in huSC18
and swIowa30) that make a positively charged lysine
fence: K133a, K145 and K222 are positioned to
provides optimal contacts with sugars beyond the
extension region of the LSTc receptor.
been proposed that amino acid residues around the
receptor binding site aﬀect virus binding to the
